content.text: Define acceleration
On Fig. 1.2, sketch a graph to show how the speed of the rocket varies between time \(t = 0\) and time \(t = t_{\mathrm{f}}\)
State the principle of the conservation of momentum
Explain how the principle of the conservation of momentum applies to the accelerating rocket and the exhaust gases
Some time later, the rocket is far from the Earth. The effect of the Earth's gravity on the motion of the rocket is insignificant. As the rocket accelerates, its momentum increases
A rocket is stationary on the launchpad. At time \(t = 0\), the rocket engines are switched on and exhaust gases are ejected from the nozzles of the engines. The rocket accelerates upwards
Fig. 1.1 shows how the acceleration of the rocket varies between time \(t = 0\) and time \(t = t_{\mathrm{f}}\)
Calculate the weight \(W\) of the sign
Calculate the moment about P due to the weight of the sign
A concrete block is positioned on the other side of the support post with its centre of mass a horizontal distance of \(70 \text{cm}\) from the centre of the support post
1. State what is meant by centre of mass
2. The weight of the concrete block produces a moment about point P that exactly cancels the moment caused by the weight \(W.\)
Calculate the weight of the concrete block
The weight of the sign acts at a horizontal distance of \(1.8 \text{m}\) from the centre of the support post and it produces a turning effect about point P
Point P is a horizontal distance of \(1.3 \text{m}\) from the centre of the support post
The concrete block is removed. The sign and support post rotate about point P in a clockwise direction
State and explain what happens to the moment about point P due to the weight of the sign as it rotates
Fig. 2.1 shows a sign that extends over a road
The mass of the sign is \(3.4 \times 10^{3} \text{kg}\)
Explain, in terms of air molecules, how the force due to the pressure of the air is produced
the pressure due to the liquid at a depth of 0.028 m
pressure =
the force on the bottom face of the cube caused by the pressure due to the liquid
The density of the liquid in the container is \(1500 \text{kg} /\text{m}^3\)
Calculate:
Calculate the work done on the cube by the force in **(b)**(ii)
work done =   .........
Suggest one reason why this is not an efficient method of lifting up the cube
The valve is opened and liquid is pumped into the container. The surface of the liquid rises a distance of \(0.034 \text{m}\)
The cube remains floating in the liquid with its bottom face \(0.028 \text{m}\) below the surface of the liquid
A cube of side \(0.040 \text{m}\) is floating in a container of liquid. Fig. 3.1 shows that the surface of the liquid is \(0.028 \text{m}\) above the level of the bottom face of the cube
The pressure of the air above the cube exerts a force on the top face of the cube. The valve is closed
Calculate the energy required to increase the temperature of the trapped gas by \(550^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The power of the heater is \(2.4 \text{W}\)
1. Calculate how long it takes for the heater to supply the energy calculated in **(a)**(i)
2. In practice, it takes much longer to increase the temperature of the gas by \(550^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) using the heater
Suggest **one** reason for this
The specific heat capacity of the gas is \(0.72 \text{J} / (\text{g} \degree \text{C})\)
State and explain what happens to the piston
Determine the volume of the gas when the piston stops moving

When the temperature of the gas has increased by \(550^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), its pressure is \(2.9 \times 10^{5}\mathrm{Pa}\). The catch is then released allowing the piston to move. As the piston moves, the temperature of the gas remains constant
Gas of mass \(0.23 \text{g}\) is trapped in a cylinder by a piston. The gas is at atmospheric pressure which is \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\). Fig. 4.1 shows the piston held in position by a catch
The volume of the trapped gas is \(1.9 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}^3\)
An electrical heater is used to increase the temperature of the trapped gas by \(550^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
State two ways in which boiling differs from evaporation
Before injecting a patient, a doctor wipes a small amount of a volatile liquid on to the patient's skin
Explain, in terms of molecules, how this procedure cools the patient's skin
In both boiling and evaporation, a liquid changes into a gas
Gases can be compressed but liquids are incompressible
Explain, in terms of molecules, why liquids are incompressible
Liquids and gases are two states of matter
The light travels more slowly in the transparent solid
Explain, in terms of the wavefronts, why the light changes direction as it enters the solid. You may draw on Fig. 6.1 as part of your answer
The light is incident on the surface of the solid at an angle of incidence of \(67^{\circ}\)
Calculate the angle of refraction of the light in the solid
angle of refraction =   .........
Determine the wavelength of the green light in the transparent solid
wavelength =   .........
The refractive index of the transparent solid is 1.3
Green light of frequency \(5.7 \times 10^{14} \text{Hz}\) is travelling in air at a speed of \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\). The light is incident on the surface of a transparent solid
Fig. 6.1 shows the wavefronts and the direction of travel of the light in the air
State the name of component X
The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery is \(E\). The switch is closed
The potential difference (p.d.) across the \(30\Omega\) resistor is \(V_{30}\)
The p.d. across the \(20\Omega\) resistor is \(V_{20}\)
The p.d. across component X is \(V_{\mathrm{x}}\)
State an equation that relates \(V_{\mathrm{x}}\) to:
the total resistance of the circuit
resistance =   .........
the ammeter reading
reading =   .........
The e.m.f. of the battery is \(6.0 \text{V}\) and the resistance of component X is \(15 \Omega\)
Calculate:
The temperature of component X increases
State and explain what happens to the ammeter reading
Fig. 7.1 shows a circuit diagram that includes component X
Explain why rotating the coil produces an output voltage
State the position of the rotating coil when the alternating output voltage is at a maximum value and explain why the maximum output occurs at this position
There is an alternating voltage output between the two terminals
A lamp and an open switch are connected in series to the output terminals of the a.c. generator
The switch is closed and the lamp lights up. The student has to apply a greater force on the handle
Explain why a greater force is needed to keep the lamp lit
A student turns the handle of an alternating current (a.c.) generator and the coil rotates
Fig. 8.1 represents the structure of the a.c. generator
The majority of the \(\alpha\) -particles pass through the gold sheet undeflected and are detected on the far side
deduction
explanation
A small number of \(\alpha\) -particles are deflected as they pass through the gold sheet
deduction
explanation
A very small number of \(\alpha\) -particles are deflected through very large angles or return back the way they came
deduction
explanation
Fig. 9.1 shows a beam of \(\alpha \cdot\) particles moving towards a thin sheet of gold in a vacuum
Detectors in the region surrounding the thin gold sheet detect the \(\alpha\) -particles and determine the number of particles that travel in various directions
State and explain what can be deduced from the following observations
A beam that consists of both \(\alpha \cdot\) -particles and \(\beta \cdot\) -particles is passed through a region of space where there is a magnetic field perpendicular to the direction of the beam
State **two** ways in which the deflection of the \(\alpha\) -particles differs from that of the \(\beta\) -particles
